Actually, I believe that what Agitar does =
is different from what Bradley is
asking.  If I understood correctly, Agita=
r monitors test runs, analyzes what
values are passed to your tests and the=
n creates more tests with
combinations of these values.

From my experience=
, what Bradley is trying to achieve is *very* common and
I've seen many occ=
urrences of companies storing months of test results in
databases, XML file=
s or Excel spreadsheet.  It's invaluable to get a sense
of the velocity of =
the quality of your product.

As for a practical solution, it seems to me i=
t should be pretty easy to
write this kind of support as a test plug-in tha=
t would monitor the test
results and store them in the right place, but I'm=
